Consider a NoSQL datastore when:: You have high volume workloads that require predictable latency at large scale (for example, latency measured in milliseconds while performing millions of transactions per second)
Consider a relational database when:: Your workload volume generally fits within thousands of transactions per second

Consider a NoSQL datastore when:: Your data is dynamic and frequently changes
Consider a relational database when:: Your data is highly structured and requires referential integrity

Consider a NoSQL datastore when:: Relationships can be de-normalized data models
Consider a relational database when:: Relationships are expressed through table joins on normalized data models

Consider a NoSQL datastore when:: Data retrieval is simple and expressed without table joins
Consider a relational database when:: You work with complex queries and reports

Consider a NoSQL datastore when:: Data is typically replicated across geographies and requires finer control over consistency, availability, and performance
Consider a relational database when:: Data is typically centralized, or can be replicated regions asynchronously

Consider a NoSQL datastore when:: Your application will be deployed to commodity hardware, such as with public clouds
Consider a relational database when:: Your application will be deployed to large, high- end hardware
